summary: Jim Garrison was the District Attorney of New Orleans who conducted his own investigation into the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. He believed that the assassination was the result of a conspiracy involving individuals and organizations beyond Lee Harvey Oswald. The documents indicate that Garrison's investigation and his interest in individuals connected to the assassination, such as David Ferrie, drew the attention of various agencies, including the CIA and FBI. The Bertrand Russell Peace Foundation contacted him to write an article about the Kennedy assassination. The documents span from 1967 to 1978, reflecting the period of Garrison's active investigation and the subsequent inquiries into the assassination.
significance: Jim Garrison's significance in the JFK assassination context lies in his role as a vocal proponent of a conspiracy theory and his efforts to prosecute individuals he believed were involved in the assassination. His investigation, though controversial, brought attention to alternative theories and raised questions about the official narrative of the assassination.
